Future potential changes in rainfall erosivity can be projected using precipitation data from General Circulation Models (GCM)
20 under different greenhouse gases emissions scenarios that follow the various Representative Concentration Pathways (RCPs) of the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change 5 th Assessment Report
21 . However, GCMs usually provide global data at a rather coarse resolution (grid size about 100–200 km) so that for climate change impact studies, it is usually necessary to downscale GCM simulations using Regional Climate Models (RCM) to provide spatially more detailed data and resolve regional or local forcings
22 .
